dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRAHAM sits in the passenger seat of a sedan that lies sk on the gravel shoulder, red lights playing on the passeng side window. He's black, thirties, staring off, either da or grappling with a very deep thought. GRAHAM (continuing) We're always behind metal and glass. Think we miss that touch so much, we crash into each other just to feel something. He looks to the driver, RIA, American-born Hispanic, thir heart racing, breathing hard, but watching Graham with re concern. A MOTORCYCLE COP appears at her open window.

dialogues.speaker: MOTORCYCLE COP
dialogues.text: You two all right?

dialogues.speaker: RIA
dialogues.text: I think he mighta hit his head.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: You don't think that's true?

dialogues.speaker: MOTORCYCLE COP
dialogues.text: Stay in your car. The officer moves off. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: RIA
dialogues.text: Graham, we were rear-ended. We spun around twice. Somewhere in there one of us lost our frame of reference. I'm gonna go look for it. She climbs out. Graham looks off through his side window. The reflections from emergency lights and flares play on face; too many lights for a simple traffic accident.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ria walks toward the Volvo that just rear-ended them. Its driver, KIM LEE, an agitated Korean woman, screams at the motorcycle cop in Korean. Burning flares squeeze traffic down to one lane, a cop herds the cars into line.

dialogues.speaker: MOTORCYCLE COP
dialogues.text: Calm down, ma'am!

dialogues.speaker: KIM LEE
dialogues.text: I am calm!

dialogues.speaker: MOTORCYCLE COP
dialogues.text: I need to see your registration and insurance.

dialogues.speaker: KIM LEE
dialogues.text: Why? Not my fault! Her fault! She do this!

dialogues.speaker: RIA
dialogues.text: (approaching) I do this?

dialogues.speaker: MOTORCYCLE COP
dialogues.text: Ma'am, wait in your vehicle.

dialogues.speaker: KIM LEE
dialogues.text: Stop in middle of street! Mexicans! No know how to drive! She blake too fast!

dialogues.speaker: RIA
dialogues.text: I "blake" too fast?? Oh, sorry, you no see my "blake lights?"

dialogues.speaker: MOTORCYCLE COP
dialogues.text: Ma-am-- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: RIA
dialogues.text: (to Kim Lee) I blake when I see long line cars stop in front of me. You see over steering wheel, maybe you blake, too.

dialogues.speaker: MOTORCYCLE COP
dialogues.text: (to Ria) Ma'am--

dialogues.speaker: KIM LEE
dialogues.text: Crazy Mexican! I call immigration on you! Look you do my car!

dialogues.speaker: RIA
dialogues.text: (to cop) Can you just write in your report how shocked I am to have been hit by an Asian driver?

dialogues.speaker: MOTORCYCLE COP
dialogues.text: Ma'am--

dialogues.speaker: RIA
dialogues.text: (flashing badge) It's not Ma'am, it's Detective.

dialogues.speaker: MOTORCYCLE COP
dialogues.text: Oh, Christ.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: He pops the flashing red light onto the dash and steps ou the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graham folds his collar against the cold and crosses the dark street that cuts through this patch of oil fields in the center of Inglewood. The argument rages in the background:

dialogues.speaker: KIM LEE
dialogues.text: No care you cop, wanna see insurance! Stupid wetback blake my car! (etc.) Graham steps toward a swarm of activity that has nothing do with the collision that just occurred -- three police cars, a coroner's vehicle and crime scene tape tells us (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: something nasty happened down in the long grass of the irrigation ditch. He dips under the crime scene tape.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE CARR
dialogues.text: a bored-looking man lighting a cigarette and staring at t ditch. Graham steps up and watches with him.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE CARR
dialogues.text: You okay?

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Freezing.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE CARR
dialogues.text: Heard it might snow.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Get outta here.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE CARR
dialogues.text: That's what I heard.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: You got a smoke?

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE CARR
dialogues.text: (blowing out smoke) Quit.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Me, too. Carr hands Graham a cigarette. He can't help glancing at Ria's escalating battle. He looks to Graham, the question implied. Graham gives him a shrug: "don't go there." Carr understands completely.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What have you got? A tech passes, heading into the crime scene.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE CARR
dialogues.text: Dead kid. Graham notices something odd and walks down into the gull

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE CARR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You touch anything and it's yours. He kneels to inspect a piece of evidence hidden in the ta weeds. A feeling starts to creep over him. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Not a good feeling. As he looks up we FADE TO BLACK. Supe TODAY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The handgun slides onto the counter. The hand belongs to DIRK, the impatient salesman.

dialogues.speaker: DIRK, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You get one free box of ammunition, what kind you want? Widen to see we're --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FARHAD, Iranian, 50s, looks at the handgun and turns to h daughter DORRI, 25, who wears a blue suit and a bad mood.

dialogues.speaker: FARHAD
dialogues.text: (in Farsi) What did he say "ammunition"?

dialogues.speaker: DORRI
dialogues.text: (in Farsi) He asked what kind of bullets you want.

dialogues.speaker: FARHAD
dialogues.text: (in Farsi) The kind that fit in the gun!

dialogues.speaker: DORRI
dialogues.text: (in Farsi) There's more than one type.

dialogues.speaker: FARHAD
dialogues.text: (in Farsi) How do I know? I don't know anything about bullets.

dialogues.speaker: DORRI
dialogues.text: (in Farsi) Which is a really good reason not to be buying a gun. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FARHAD
dialogues.text: (in Farsi) You don't use that tone of voice with me.

dialogues.speaker: DIRK
dialogues.text: Yo, Osama, plan the Jihad on your own time; what do you want?

dialogues.speaker: FARHAD
dialogues.text: (in Farsi) What is he saying about Jihad? (to Dirk, in English:) Are you making insults at me?

dialogues.speaker: DIRK
dialogues.text: Am I making insults at you?? That's the closest you get to English?

dialogues.speaker: FARHAD
dialogues.text: I am American citizen--!

dialogues.speaker: DIRK
dialogues.text: (here it comes) --Oh, God.

dialogues.speaker: FARHAD
dialogues.text: --I have rights like you! I have right to buy gun! Dirk pulls the gun back to his side of the counter.

dialogues.speaker: DIRK
dialogues.text: Not from my store, you don't. Dirk nods toward the Security Guard, who heads this way. Dorri sees him coming.

dialogues.speaker: DORRI
dialogues.text: Go wait in the car, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: FARHAD
dialogues.text: (to Dirk) You are ignorant man!

dialogues.speaker: DIRK
dialogues.text: Yeah, I'm ignorant; you're liberating my country and I'm flying 747s into your mud huts and incinerating your friends. Get the fuck out of my store. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SEC. GUARD FARHAD
dialogues.text: (taking his arm) You don't touch! This man Let's go. cheats me!

dialogues.speaker: DORRI
dialogues.text: (to Farhad) Do you want to get arrested? Go wait in the car, Dad! Farhad storms out, the security guard following. Dorri lo the salesman dead in the eye:

dialogues.speaker: DORRI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You can give me the gun or give me the money back, and I'm really hoping for the money. Dirk looks Dorri up and down, gives her a lecherous smile and slides the gun back across the counter.

dialogues.speaker: DIRK
dialogues.text: And what kind of ammunition do you want?

dialogues.speaker: DORRI
dialogues.text: Whatever fits.

dialogues.speaker: DIRK
dialogues.text: Oh, we got a lot of things that fit. We got long colts, short colts, ball heads, flat-nose, hollow points, wad cutters and a dozen more that all fit in the same size hole, just depends how big a "bang" you can handle.

dialogues.speaker: DORRI
dialogues.text: (pointing) I'll take the ones in the red box.

dialogues.speaker: DIRK
dialogues.text: (looks; looks back) ...-Do you know what those are?

dialogues.speaker: DORRI
dialogues.text: Can I have them? He takes the box with a snort and places it on the counte with the gun. Dorri snatches them up and exits.  3/18/04 8.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A couple opens the door and enters a moderately priced It restaurant; call the guy ALLAN, call his date angry.

dialogues.speaker: ALLAN
dialogues.text: No, please tell me: what "sin" did I commit this time? And we lose them as ANTHONY flies out the door, PETER jus one step behind him. They're in their early twenties, you hip, well-dressed black men, friends since third grade. They button their jackets as they head down the sidewalk.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY
dialogues.text: You see any white people in there waiting an hour and thirty two minutes for a plate of spaghetti? Huh? And how many cups of coffee did we get?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: You don't drink coffee and I didn't want any.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY
dialogues.text: That woman poured cup after cup to every white person around us. Did she even ask you if you wanted any?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: We didn't get any coffee that you didn't want and I didn't order, and this is evidence of racial discrimination? Did you happen to notice our waitress was black?

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY
dialogues.text: And black women don't think in stereotypes? When's the last time you met one who didn't think she knew everything about your lazy ass before you even opened your mouth? That waitress sized us up in two seconds. We're black and "black people don't tip" so she wasn't gonna waste her time; someone like that, nothing you can do to change their mind. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: So how much you leave her? The angry girl runs past them.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY
dialogues.text: You expect me to pay for that kinda service?? Peter laughs; Anthony doesn't. Allan runs by chasing his date.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ...What? What? Hey, come on! I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Nothing, nothing. The camera whips around with Allan. We lose him as he cut across the street, and find RICK & JEAN CABOT, white, ear 40s, step out of the Blockbuster and head for their car. Jean pulls her jacket closed as they walk.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: You're seriously jealous of Karen??

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Hardly. I'd just like to see you get through a meal without calling her, or someone else at your office.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: (re: cell phone) See this? Off. No more calls tonight . Jean notices Anthony and Peter and takes Rick's arm.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Ten bucks says she calls on the car phone.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY
dialogues.text: You see what that woman just did?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: She's cold, man. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY
dialogues.text: She got colder soon as she saw us.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: --Here it comes.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY
dialogues.text: Look around! You couldn't find a whiter, safer or better lit part of this city. But this white woman sees two black guys, who look like UCLA students, strolling down the sidewalk and her reaction is blind fear. I mean, look at us! Are we dressed like gangbangers? Do we look threatening? No. Fact, if anybody should be scared, it's us: the only two black faces surrounded by a sea of over-caffeinated white people, patrolled by the trigger- happy LAPD. So, why aren't we scared?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Because we have guns?

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY
dialogues.text: You could be right. Both men reach into their clothing and come out with Satu night specials. They rush toward Rick's black Navigator.

dialogues.speaker: PETER JEAN
dialogues.text: Away from the car! Oh my God! Oh my God! Away from the car! Rick!

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY RICK
dialogues.text: Gimme the keys! Gimme Don't shoot, just don't the keys! Shut up and shoot. give me the keys!

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Walk away! Walk away! Turn around and walk!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anthony hops into the driver's seat, screaming for Peter:

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY
dialogues.text: Get in! Get in! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Unlock the door! Anthony does. Peter hops in as Anthony sparks the ignitio To Peter's surprise Anthony hops back out...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ..-.and he aims his gun at Rick and Jean's back.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY
dialogues.text: Stop!! They freeze. Anthony runs up, grabs the DVD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anthony drops into the seat and tosses the DVD at Peter.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (reading label) Haven't seen it. Anthony shifts into first and screams out of there. Peter digs into his pocket and pulls out a plastic St. Christop statuette. He licks the suction cup and sticks it on the dashboard.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY
dialogues.text: No! No! Take that voodoo-ass thing off there right now! Look at the marks it makes!

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: You're calling St. Christopher voodoo? Man's the patron saint of travelers.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY
dialogues.text: God talk to you, did he? What did he say? "Go forth my son and leave big, slobbery suction rings on every dashboard you find??" Why the hell do you do that?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Look at the way you drive, then ask me again!  3/18/04 12.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A squad car wipes, revealing a sea of flashing red lights A Mercedes sits in middle of it all, doors open, body on ground beside it. Uniformed cops stand around pretending they are actually doing something. One of them leads us t

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM AND RIA
dialogues.text: who walk from their unmarked sedan, accompanied by a unif cop, OFFICER JOHNSON.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Ford pickup and Mercedes driving North on Hill. The pickup cuts in front. Driver of the Mercedes gets pissed, pulls a gun -- he doesn't realize the guy in the pickup is a cop coming off shift.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: That the cop? He nods toward a tall man, long stringy hair, sipping a c and leaning against a squad car, chatting with two unifor

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Yeah. Name is Conklin. He's a Narc out of Wilshire. You want to talk to him?

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Not yet.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Mercedes takes a shot at him. Detective Conklin returns fire, one shot. Mercedes hits the wall, driver opens the door and falls out dead.

dialogues.speaker: RIA
dialogues.text: I got the Mercedes. Ria splits off toward the Mercedes.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: (ve: Conklin) Looks pretty relaxed for having shot a man. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Coming up on Conklin's Ford pickup:

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER JOHNSON
dialogues.text: He says he kept trying to drive away but the Mercedes kept pulling up next to him, the gun. Shot back Graham stoops to see a bullet

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Anyone see who shot

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER
dialogues.text: They just heard two screaming, waving in self-defense. hole in the driver's door. first?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNSON
dialogues.text: bangs.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Find me a witness. Graham splits off and arrives examines the body of the dead in his head. A pearl handled at the Mercedes, where Ria black driver, a bullet wound revolver lies on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Nice gun.

dialogues.speaker: RIA
dialogues.text: One bullet fired. The car is registered to Cindy Bradley. That's not his name. His name is William Lewis. (hands him a wallet) It was under the front seat. Graham opens the wallet, revealing a Detective's Badge.

dialogues.speaker: RIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (looking at dead cop's business card) Hollywood Division. Graham lets out a low whistle, then throws a look to Conk

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Looks like Detective Conklin shot himself the wrong nigga. As Graham stands we cut to:  3/18/04 14. 10 INT. CARNEY'S - STUDIO CITY -- NIGHT 10Â° Crowded with patrons who order hot drinks. We SLIDE PAST two Korean businessmen. CHOI JIN GUIH, late 40's, dressed well, sits across the table from the younger looking PARK Park rips a check out of his checkbook, hands it to Choi.

dialogues.speaker: PARK
dialogues.text: How soon can I have them? Choi folds the check and stuffs it in his wallet.

dialogues.speaker: CHOT
dialogues.text: Tonight. I'm picking them up right now. Good doing business with you. Choi shakes Park's hand and heads out the back door.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I keep telling you he's in pain. He can't sleep. Choi passes OFFICER RYAN on the pay phone by the door. He white, in uniform, and angry.

dialogues.speaker: SHANIQUA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (over phone) And I told you the clinic is only open after hours for emergencies--

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: --This is an emergency--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHANIQUA, a very tired black administrator is on the othe end of the line.

dialogues.speaker: SHANIQUA
dialogues.text: --Mr. Ryan, your father has been to the clinic three times in the last month. He's being treated for a urinary tract infection that is by no means an emergency. If you have any more questions about your HMO plan, you can make an appointment to come in from ten to four, Monday through Friday. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: What does my father do about sleeping tonight?

dialogues.speaker: SHANIQUA
dialogues.text: I don't know. I'm not a doctor.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: I want to speak to your supervisor.

dialogues.speaker: SHANIQUA
dialogues.text: I am my supervisor.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: What's your name?

dialogues.speaker: SHANIQUA
dialogues.text: Shaniqua Johnson.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: Big fucking surprise that is. Ryan hears the click and hangs up, exits...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .-approaches his partner TOM HANSEN, who stirs his

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: Call any big company with a problem; why is the person you have to deal with guaranteed to be black and stupid? Why? Because corporations are smart. They actually seek out the stupidest fucking black people they can find. They want us to get so frustrated that we'll go away and they won't have to spend their fucking money. (walking off) Genius. Hansen stirs some more. As RYAN exits to the parking lot white panel van stops at the sidewalk, CHOI driving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Ryan and Hansen climb in they hear: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DISPATCHER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Black late model Navigator, California plate: 4PCI315.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A black Navigator passes, a 40ish black man at the wheel.

dialogues.speaker: DISPATCHER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Suspects are two black males, approximately 20 years of age, armed and dangerous.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN 16
dialogues.text: Pulls out to follow.

dialogues.speaker: HANSEN
dialogues.text: It's not it. (no response) It's not the vehicle. The plates don't match, the driver's in his forties, and nobody jacks a car and takes it to Studio City. Ryan hits the flashers.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIGATOR ON RESIDENTIAL STREET AHEAD
dialogues.text: A woman pops up in the passenger seat. She may have been napping in the driver's lap, or she may have been doing something else. She throws a look back at the cop car. Caught in the headlights her face looks chalk white.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN 18
dialogues.text: Sees her face and bumps the siren.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: They were doing something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Navigator pulls to a stop under a street lamp, the sq car pulls up behind. Ryan steps out. Hansen clearly doesn like this; nonetheless, he steps out and assumes the back position. Ryan approaches the window, unsnapping his hols

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: Keep your hands in plain sight. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: RYAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I need to see your license and registration. Behind the wheel, CAMERON THAYER, 40ish, black, tucks his shirt back into his tuxedo pants and digs out his wallet.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: No problem. Ryan looks to the passenger reapplying her lipstick: CHRI THAYER, strikingly beautiful, light-skinned black woman i cocktail dress. She may have had a bit too much to drink.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: Evening.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: (suppressing a smile) How are you tonight, officer?

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: I need to reach into the glove compartment to get the registration.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: Do it slowly, please. Ryan lays his hand on his Glock as Cameron reaches over t get his papers. Ryan's flashlight beam glides from the gl compartment to Christine's breasts, then up to her face.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: Here you go. He slowly hands the documents to Ryan.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: Stay in the vehicle, please. He walks back to the squad car and hands the license and registration to Hansen and returns to the Navigator.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Step onto the sidewalk, please, sir.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: I haven't been drinking. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: Then we shouldn't have a problem.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: He doesn't drink. He's a Buddhist for Christ's sake.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: It's okay, Christine.

dialogues.speaker: BACK IN THE SQUAD CAR
dialogues.text: runs the license, keeping his eye on Cameron as he steps around to the sidewalk.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: (to Cameron) Stand on your right foot and touch your nose with the index finger of your left hand. As Cameron does...

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: steps out of the car.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: I told you he doesn't drink.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: Ma'am, I'm only going to tell you one time to wait in the vehicle.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: "Matam??"

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: Get in the car, Christine.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: Don't you "Matam" me, I'm not your fucking mammy. Ryan motions for his partner to join him as...

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: Both of you, turn around, hands on your head, interlock your fingers. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: Officer, we're a block from home --

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: Don't talk to me, put your hands on your head and interlock your fingers.

dialogues.speaker: HANSEN CAMERON
dialogues.text: (approaching) I'm a television director, What have we got? my wife and I just came back from an awards dinner-- Ryan grabs Cameron's wrist and slams him up against the truck...

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: What did I just tell you? ...and kicks his feet out. Cam puts his hands on his head

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: Get your hands off him!

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: (to Hansen) Pat him down. (to Christine) Put your hands on your head, ma'am. Hansen reluctantly pats Cameron down.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: Do what he says.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: (to Cameron) Fuck you! (to Ryan) And you keep your filthy fuckin' hands off me! Ryan takes her wrist and twists her into the car face fir kicking her feet out from under her.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ow! You fucking pig!

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: Christine, stop talking. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: That's quite a mouth you have. (to Cameron) Course, you know that.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: Fuck you. That's why you're doing this, isn't it? You thought you saw a white woman blowing a black man and that just drove your little cracker ass crazy!

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: Christine, shut your goddamn mouth!

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: I'd listen to your husband, Ma'am. Ryan runs his hands up the sides of her torso...

dialogues.speaker: RYAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you have any guns or knives on you, anything I'm going to get stuck with?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: I'm wearing a cocktail dress, what do you think?

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: You'd be surprised the places I've found weapons. He slides his hands over the sides of her breasts. pretends not to see, as he quickly frisks Cameron. turns her head so she catches her husband's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: HANSEN
dialogues.text: Clean. But Ryan is nowhere near finished.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: (to Cameron) So, what do you think we should do about this, Mr. Thayer? Ryan squats and runs his hands down to her ankles... (CONTINUED)
Hansen Christine 19  19 3/18/04 21.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My partner and I just witnessed your wife performing fellatio on you while you were operating a motor vehicle. Now his hands start up the inside of her calves.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That's reckless endangerment... Hansen looks away, knowing this is bullshit.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ...which is a felony. Then we could charge your wife here with lewd conduct and performing a sexual act in public. His hands reach up her thighs into her dress and linger t Christine looks away from her husband, her rage replaced humiliation.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now, you say you're a block from home. We can use our discretion, let you go with a warning. Or we can cuff you and put you in the back of the car. Ryan removes his hands.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What do you think we should do?

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: We're...sorry. We'd appreciate it if you'd...just give us a warning.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: (to Hansen) Man's apologizing, Tommy. I think we can let them go, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: HANSEN
dialogues.text: Yeah. Ryan looks into Christine's face, daring her to say anyth She doesn't. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: Fine. You can go.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: ...Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: No problem. (walking away) You folks drive safe now. Christine climbs into the passenger seat as Cameron circl the vehicle.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE NAVIGATOR
dialogues.text: Cameron gets in the driver's seat, sees Christine is shak Puts his hand on hers. She pulls it away. Cameron starts the car and drives off.

dialogues.speaker: HANSEN
dialogues.text: watches them go. A decision made, he drops into his seat and closes the car door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHEREEN, Farhad's wife, repeatedly slams the back door. Unlike her daughter, she wears traditional dress.

dialogues.speaker: SHEREEN
dialogues.text: It won't close. FARHAD stands with Dorri as she loads the gun from the am box.

dialogues.speaker: FARHAD
dialogues.text: Pull it hard. She keeps trying as....

dialogues.speaker: FARHAD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Dorri) I can do that! She snaps the cylinder in place.

dialogues.speaker: DORRI
dialogues.text: You couldn't even get it open. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FARHAD
dialogues.text: (in Farsi) You have no respect for your father anymore? Give me the gun.

dialogues.speaker: DORRI
dialogues.text: There. Now you can shoot anybody you want. She hands him the gun and ammo. He turns on his heel and exits. Dorri follows him into THE FRONT OF THE STORE. Far pops open a hidden drawer under the cash register and pla the gun and ammo in it.

dialogues.speaker: FARHAD
dialogues.text: That man could have killed your mother. You think I should let crazy people do what they want to us? Shereen comes out from the back room.

dialogues.speaker: SHEREEN
dialogues.text: Farhad, it won't close. Farhad disappears into the back room.

dialogues.speaker: SHEREEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Dorri) You should be at work. Dorri turns and exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The stolen black Navigator screams around the corner into barren strip of Los Angles, hip-hop blaring from its speakers.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: No, you want to listen to music of the Oppressor, you go right ahead.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: How in the lunacy of your mind is Hip-Hop "music of the Oppressor??" (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY
dialogues.text: Listen to it! Nigga-this, nigga that; you think white people walk around calling each other honkies?? "Hey, Honky, how's business?" "Goin! great, Cracker, we're diversifying." Peter punches the radio, a country western singer wails.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: This better? You like this? Man's singing about lynchin' a nigga.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY
dialogues.text: And you think there's a difference?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (singing) "Gonna buy me a rope, and lynch me a niggaaaaaaa..."

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY
dialogues.text: You got no idea where Hip-Hop comes from, do you?

dialogues.speaker: THE ROAD AHEAD
dialogues.text: Almost deserted; they fly past small factories and busine closed for the night. Only one vehicle in sight, a panel van parked way up ahead on this side of the street.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Back in the sixties we (wailing and twanging) had smart, articulate "I'd shoot him dead first, black men. Huey Newton, but I done broke my Bobby Seale, Eldridge triggaaaaaaaaaa...... Cleaver, Fred Hampton; Gonna get out my sheet, these brothers were put my hood on my heaaaad... speaking out and people were listening. A Korean man steps out from in front of the van, stops at the driver's door, searching his pockets. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY PETER
dialogues.text: The FBI said: "Oh, we "Gonna string him up good, can't have that." and then he'll be deaaaad." "I know! Let's give the niggers this music by a bunch of mumbling idiots-- Anthony takes his eyes off the road.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY PETER
dialogues.text: --and they'll all copy (chorus: ) it and sooner or later "In the home of the brave no one will be able to and the land of the freeeee. understand a fuckin' Gonna have black boys word they say! End of swinging, from each old problem!" oak treeeeee." BAM! They hit something. Both heads snap front, see nothing. They spin around to look behind them: nothing th either.

dialogues.speaker: THE DOOR OF THE PANEL VAN 23
dialogues.text: A set of keys sway back and forth in the lock.

dialogues.speaker: BACK IN THE SPEEDING NAVIGATOR 24
dialogues.text: Anthony looks to Peter.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY
dialogues.text: What the fuck was that? As Anthony stomps on the brakes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Navigator skids to a stop and they hop out. Peter loo under the fender and comes flying back up.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Holy shit, we run over a Chinaman!

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY
dialogues.text: You're saying there's a Chinaman under this truck? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: What do you not understand? There's a Chinaman stuck under the goddamn truck! Anthony bends down, looks right into the bleeding face of the Korean man. Anthony pops up like he's just been shot.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY
dialogues.text: Where the hell did he come from?!

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Fuckin' China! What do you mean where'd he come from?!

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY
dialogues.text: He was standing in the street?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: No, I think he comes with the truck, Anthony! It's an option now, for people who don't want to go through all the trouble of running over their own fucking Buddhahead!

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY
dialogues.text: What the hell he do, leap out in front of the truck?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I don't know, maybe the FBI planted him under there to make car-jacking black people look bad in the eyes of the larger community. You got a theory about that, too?

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY
dialogues.text: This is so completely fucked.

dialogues.speaker: CHOI, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Help me.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY
dialogues.text: Shut up! I'm trying to think! (paces) Fuck-fuck-fuck! Okay, come on, get back in the truck.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: What? You think we didn't drag him far enough?! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY
dialogues.text: We'll drive away, he'll let go.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: He's not gonna let go! He's stuck under the fucking truck! If he coulda let go, he probably would have considered that option half a block back! Just grab his arm, we'll pull him outta there.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY
dialogues.text: You grab his arm it's gonna fall off! You're gonna be standing in the street holding a Chinaman's arm. Then what you gonna do?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: We leave him there, the man dies, and we're up on murder charges, Einstein. Now grab his goddamn arm! Anthony relents. They reach under and as Choi screams...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christine drops her purse and snatches up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: Who are you calling?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: I'm gonna report their asses. Sons of bitches..

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: And you actually think they're going to take you seriously?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: (slams phone down) Do you have any idea what that was like to have that pig's hands all over me? And you watch him do it and then you apologize to him?? What the fuck was that about?

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: What did you want me to do, get us both shot? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: --They were gonna shoot us on Ventura Blvd??

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: So, you would have been satisfied with just being arrested.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: You're right, Cam, much better to let him shove his hand up my crotch than get your name in the paper.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: Yeah, that's what I was worried about.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: It wasn't? You weren't afraid all your good friends at the studio were gonna read about you in the morning and realize you were actually black?

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: You need to calm down here.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: No, what I need is a husband who won't just stand there while I'm being molested!

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: They were cops! They had guns! Where do you think you're living, with mommy and daddy in Greenwich?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: --Go to hell.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: Maybe I shoulda let them lock your ass up. I guess sooner or later you should learn what it's like to be black.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: Fuck you, like you know. Closest you ever came to being black was watching the Cosby Show. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: At least I wasn't watching it with the rest of the equestrian team.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: You know, you're right, Cam, I got a lot to learn. 'Cause I haven't quite learned how to shuck and jive. Let me hear it again: "Thank you, Mr. Poh-liceman. You sure is kind to us po' black folk. You be sure to let me know next time you wanna finger-fuck my wife."

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: You know what? Fuck you.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: Oh that's good. A little anger. A bit late, but nice to see. He slams out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jean's feet descend the stairs to the expansive kitchen, where DANIEL, the Hispanic locksmith, re-keys the door. He's twentyish, close-cropped hair, baggy pants, tattoos.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: How much longer are you going to be?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: This is the last door.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Thanks. She exits, walking through the butler's pantry into the d room, where several staff members work. She turns into th living room, where Rick and two aides work up strategy.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Nothing from Parker Center.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: (interrupting) I need to talk to you. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She exits without waiting for a response. Rick turns to KAREN, his top aide (young, black, brilliant), who is on Trio, laptop in front of her.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Just find Flanagan. Karen dials as Rick exits to the...

dialogues.speaker: THE HALL OFF THE KITCHEN
dialogues.text: where Jean waits, arms crossed so tightly they're squeezi all the air out of her lungs.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: I want the locks changed again in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Honey, why don't you go bed. Did you check on James?

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Of course I checked on James, I've checked him every five minutes since we've been home, don't patronize me! I want the locks changed again in the morning!

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Shhh, it's okay. You just need to lie down.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Didn't I just ask you not to treat me like a child?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Sorry, Mrs. Jean... It's MARIA, their Salvadoran housekeeper and babysitter, sweater and bag in her arm.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Yes, Maria? Jean turns away, livid.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Is okay I leave now? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Yeah, sure, thanks for staying.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: No problem. Good-night, Mrs. Jean.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Good-night. Maria exits. Jean speaks to Rick as if English is his sec language:

dialogues.speaker: JEAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I want the locks changed again in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Jean--

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: And you could mention that we'd appreciate it if next time they didn't send a gang member.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: (lowering his voice) ..-You're talking about that kid in there?

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Shaved head, pants down around his ass, prison tattoos?

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Oh for Christ sakes, those aren't prison tattoos!

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Right, and he isn't going to sell our key to one of his gang-banger friends the moment he's out the door.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Jean, it's been a tough night. Why don't you go upstairs and--

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: --wait for them to break in? (now in a rage) I just had a gun pointed in my face! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: (sotto) Lower your voice!

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: --And it's my fault, because I knew it was going to happen! But if a white person sees two black men walking toward them and turns and walks the other way, she's a racist, right? Well, I got scared and I didn't say anything and ten seconds later I had a gun in my face! Now I'm telling you that your amigo in there is going to sell our house key to one of his homies! And this time it'd be really fucking nice if you acted like you actually cared!! Jean turns and storms into the kitchen. Rick stares at he as she makes a show of wiping down the counter.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: throws a look over her shoulder toward the backdoor, sees

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: packing up his tools, looking right back at her.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: looks away and busies herself with the dishes.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: turns and walks back to the...

dialogues.speaker: THE LIVING ROOM 28
dialogues.text: BRUCE, his second aide, works on a way to spin this. Kare snaps her cell phone closed and turns to Rick.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Flanagan doesn't think anyone has the story yet.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Flanagan's an idiot. We're talking minutes. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: I've called a friend at KCBS--

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: --Bruce, you can call God himself: I'm the fucking District Attorney! I get my car jacked, it's gonna make the news. Christ, why did they have to be black?! No matter how we spin this I'm gonna either lose the black vote or the fucking law and order vote. I got West Side Jews up the ass; aren't there any Hasidic kids going bad?

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Do you have to say they were black?

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: You're right, Bruce, I should have told my own cops that I couldn't quite make out the color of two men standing less than a foot from me. Give yourself a raise.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: I think you're worrying too much. You have a lot support in the black community.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: So did Gil Garcetti. Remember him? Former DA, tall guy, had that little run-in with oJ?

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: They stole your car at gunpoint in the middle of Westwood!

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Check the LA Weekly tomorrow, I'll be the one with the gun in my hand. Tf we can't duck this thing we have to neutralize it. You know what I need? I need a black man I can pin a medal on. I need a picture of me pinning a medal on a fucking black man. What about that fire fighter who saved those campers in-- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: He's Iraqi.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: He's Iraqi? He looked black.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Iraqi. Saddam Khahum.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Saddam? You want me to pin a medal on an Iraqi named Saddam?? Are you out of your fucking mind? And Rick blows out of the room, as Bruce wonders why he e opens his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daniel the locksmith drops his toolbox onto his seat, sta his truck and drives off, passing...

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: who steps out of her dead car and tries to wave him down, but he doesn't see her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's almost pitch black, until headlights appear on the s and sweep up the drive. The headlamp pulls right up to th camera and burns out the screen. The lamp switches off, t filament glows dimly until the scene once again dissolves black.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hall lies dark until Daniel opens the front door. He places his locksmith box onto the floor and slips out of shoes. He notices light spilling out from under a door do the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daniel eases open the door, finds the room lit by the bed lamp. The bed is stripped of its pillow and blanket, part of which sticks out from under the box spring. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: UNDER THE BED
dialogues.text: Daniel lifts the bedskirt. He kneels and lies on the floo His six year-old daughter, LARA, lies awake under the bed blanket over her shoulder, pillow scrunched under her hea

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: How ya doing?

dialogues.speaker: LARA
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: (beat) You didn't get scared or something, did you? There's no monsters in the closet? 'Cause I hate monsters.

dialogues.speaker: LARA
dialogues.text: There's no such thing as monsters.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: That's a good thing, then.

dialogues.speaker: LARA
dialogues.text: I heard a bang.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Like a truck bang?

dialogues.speaker: LARA
dialogues.text: Like a gun.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Huh. That's funny. 'Cause we moved outta that bad neighborhood, not too many guns âround here.

dialogues.speaker: LARA
dialogues.text: ....How far can bullets go?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Oh, pretty far. But they usually get stuck in something and stop.

dialogues.speaker: LARA
dialogues.text: ..-What if they don't?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: You thinking about that one that came through your window? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Lara nods.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yeah, we never did find it, did we? Lara shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: LARA
dialogues.text: I think it didn't see me, 'cause I was under the covers.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: And you think it was that same bullet you heard tonight? Lara shrugs, she thinks it is but doesn't want to say it. Daniel settles in, as if only now realizing the enormity this situation. He lies there thinking this problem throu

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Huh. You think maybe we should move again?

dialogues.speaker: LARA
dialogues.text: I like it here.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Yeah. Me, too. But if that bullet found out where we live... (realizes something) Hold on.

dialogues.speaker: LARA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: I am so stupid. How could I forget this?

dialogues.speaker: LARA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Never mind, you're not gonna believe me.

dialogues.speaker: LARA
dialogues.text: Tell me. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Okay. When I was five, this fairy came into my room one night.

dialogues.speaker: LARA
dialogues.text: (skeptical) Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: See, I told you wouldn't believe me. Okay, you go to sleep now.

dialogues.speaker: LARA
dialogues.text: No, tell me.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: -.-.Okay, so this fairy comes into my room. And I'm like, "yeah, .right, you're a fairy." Anyway, we're talking, you know, and she's flying around the room, knocking my posters down and stuff.

dialogues.speaker: LARA
dialogues.text: She was flying?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Yeah, she had these little stubby wings. But she coulda glued 'em on or something, right, I'm not gonna believe she's a fairy. So, sheâ says, "I'll prove it." And she reaches into her backpack and pulls out this invisible cloak. And she ties it around my neck, and she tells me it's impenetrable. You know what impenetrable means? (Lara shakes her head) It means nothing bad can get through it. Not bullets, nothing. And she says I should wear this cloak and nothing will ever hurt me. So, I did. And my whole life I never got shot, stabbed, nothing. I mean, how weird is that? Only she tells me I'm supposed to give it to my daughter on her sixth birthday. And I forgot.

dialogues.speaker: LARA
dialogues.text: Can I touch it? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Sure, go ahead. She touches his arm.

dialogues.speaker: LARA
dialogues.text: I can't feel it.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Pretty cool, huh? If you want, I can take it off and tie it around your shoulders, 'cause she showed me how to do that. Unless you think it's stupid.

dialogues.speaker: LARA
dialogues.text: ...Don't you need it?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Not anymore. So, what do you think? You want it? Lara waits, then nods slightly. Daniel reaches in and pul her out.

dialogues.speaker: LARA'S BED
dialogues.text: Daniel places her on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Okay. Daniel "unties" the invisible cloak and takes it off. He wraps it around her shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hold your chin up. She does. He ties it around her neck.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That too tight? She shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You feel anything at all? She shakes her head. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Good. Then it's just right. He kisses her on the forehead. He pulls out her pillow an places it on the bed. She lies down and he covers her. He turns off her light.

dialogues.speaker: LARA
dialogues.text: Do I take it off when I have a bath?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: No, you leave it on all the time. 'Till you grow up and have a daughter, and she turns six. Then you give it to her. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: LARA
dialogues.text: Okay. And he walks toward the door. Lara strokes her shoulder, trying to feel it, then closes her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daniel eases his daughter's door closed. His beeper goes off. He silences it quickly, checks the read-out, exhales

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anthony and Peter drop Choi on the sidewalk beneath the emergency sign and run back to the Navigator. As they hop in:

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY
dialogues.text: What year was that van he was driving?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: You want to steal the man's van? You already took his wallet-- As they speed off:

dialogues.speaker: PETER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: --what do you wanna do next: find his house and shoot his dog? They disappear around the corner....  35 36 3/18/04 40.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a shiny new lock. Daniel yanks open the metal doo sees that it's bowed, slams it closed and turns the bolt; only moves a quarter turn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daniel steps in from the storage room to find Farhad lock the front door.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: FARHAD
dialogues.text: I want go home, how long?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: I replaced the lock but you got a real problem with that door.

dialogues.speaker: FARHAD
dialogues.text: You fix the lock.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: I replaced the lock, but the door is bent, you gotta fix the door.

dialogues.speaker: FARHAD
dialogues.text: Fix the lock!

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Listen to me, you need a new door.

dialogues.speaker: FARHAD
dialogues.text: I need door? How much?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: I don't know, you gotta call someone who sells doors.

dialogues.speaker: FARHAD
dialogues.text: You try and cheat me, right? You have friend who fix door?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: I don't have a friend who fixes doors. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FARHAD
dialogues.text: You fix the fucking lock, you cheater! Daniel pulls out the bill -- printed on blue paper.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Listen, just pay for the lock, I won't charge you for my time.

dialogues.speaker: FARHAD
dialogues.text: You no fix but I pay? You think I'm stupid. You cheat, you fix the lock!

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: I'd really appreciate it if you'd stop calling me names.

dialogues.speaker: FARHAD
dialogues.text: You no fix the fucking lock!

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: I replaced the lock! You gotta fix the door!

dialogues.speaker: FARHAD
dialogues.text: Fucking cheat! You fucking cheat!

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: (crumples the bill) Fine. Don't pay. Have a good night. Daniel tosses the bill in the waste basket and walks out through the back...

dialogues.speaker: FARHAD
dialogues.text: You fix fucking lock! You fix fucking lock!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Porsche screams into the garage, the garage door slams right behind it. As it disappears into the cavernous room we see a couple dozen guys chopping up high-ticket cars. The Porsche parks beside the Navigator, which sits with i cargo door open. LUCIEN GREEN tosses away a rag and steps back to Peter and Anthony. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: No, I understand. You run over a Chinaman, stuff him in the back and then bring the truck here so I can share in the experience.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY
dialogues.text: It's a little bit of blood, it'll wash right off.

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: (calls off) Georgie, burn this thing. Lucien walks off as Georgie, a mountain of a man, closes rear door. Anthony and Peter follow Lucien.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY
dialogues.text: Come on, man, it's a brand new Navigator. All you need is a little piece of carpet.

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: You watch the Discovery Channel?

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY
dialogues.text: Not a lot.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: That's some good shit.

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: Every night there's a show with somebody shining a little blue light and finding tiny specs of blood spattered on carpets and walls and ceiling fans, bathroom fixtures, and special edition plastic Burger King drink cups. Then the next thing they show is some stupid redneck in handcuffs, who looks absolutely stunned that this is happening to him. Sometimes, the redneck is actually watching the Discovery Channel when they break in to arrest him. And he still can't figure out how on earth they could have caught him. Do I look like I wanna be on the Discovery Channel? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: Then get the fuck out of my shop!

dialogues.speaker: THE NAVIGATOR
dialogues.text: Georgie puts the truck in reverse as Peter reaches in to pluck St. Christopher off the dashboard.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY
dialogues.text: Yeah, make sure you get that. Because without him, things coulda gone wrong tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking in from the backyard we barely discern the two na bodies lost in each other. We hear the passionate sounds sex and find Graham in bed, on top of Ria, her legs wrapp around his back.

dialogues.speaker: RIA
dialogues.text: Oh God! Oh God yes! Yes! Her fingers dig into his back. He screams, she screams louder. That's when the phone rings.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Jesus! It rings again. He reaches for it.

dialogues.speaker: RIA
dialogues.text: Don't you dare!

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: It could be S.I.D.

dialogues.speaker: RIA
dialogues.text: Don't you--! He answers it, faking his best "just another day" voice.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: (into phone) -- Graham Waters. She pushes him off the bed. His naked body lands on the floor. He holds onto the phone, then: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (into phone) I'm sorry, this is Graham. Hello? Naked and sweaty, Ria grabs the bottle of water on the nightstand, gulps it down.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (into phone) Yeah.... No, Ma. He's not here.

dialogues.speaker: RIA
dialogues.text: (suddenly ashamed) Oh, God, it's your mother?

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: (into phone) No, I can't go looking for him. Ma? Because I can't. He'll be home, leave it alone. (finally) Ma? I gotta go, I'm having sex with a white woman. That gets Ria's attention. She gets up, searches for her clothes. He watches her.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (into phone) Ma, I'll-call you tomorrow. Bye. He hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sorry. Where were we?

dialogues.speaker: RIA
dialogues.text: (pulling on her pants) I was white and you were about to jerk off in the shower.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Oh, come on. I woulda said Mexican but it wouldn't have pissed her off as much.

dialogues.speaker: RIA
dialogues.text: That's funny, âcause if my mother knew I was sleeping with a black man, she'd never speak to me again. Where's my goddamn blouse? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: You put it on I'm just gonna have to rip it off. As she yanks on her clothes....

dialogues.speaker: RIA
dialogues.text: You gotta keep everybody at a certain distance, don't you? What happen, you start to feel something and panic?

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Ria--

dialogues.speaker: RIA
dialogues.text: Because I am so looking forward to hearing the "we can't mix career and personal life" speech. Like it's such a big mystery which one you'd choose. You don't pick a pair of socks without thinking what they're going to do for your career.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: You're pissed because I answered the phone.

dialogues.speaker: RIA
dialogues.text: That's just where I begin to get pissed. I don't know how I could have had sex with a man who could talk to his mother like that.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: This is about my mother?? What do you know about my mother?

dialogues.speaker: RIA
dialogues.text: I know if I was your father I'd give you a beating.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Yeah, I was raised badly. Take those clothes off and teach me a lesson.

dialogues.speaker: RIA
dialogues.text: You want a lesson? How about geography? My father is from Puerto Rico, my mother is from El Salvador; neither one is Mexico. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: So, then I guess the big mystery is: who gathered those remarkably different cultures together and taught them all how to park cars on their lawns? She gives him a look that should cut through to the back his head, then exits, slamming the door behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan wakes with a start, thinking he heard something. Ble eyed, in T-shirt and boxers, he steps out of his bedroom walks toward the sound of someone groaning. He stops at t bathroom door, which sits slightly ajar.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: How you doing, Pop?

dialogues.speaker: POP RYAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: If I could piss I'd be doing a lot better. (keeps himself from crying out) Jesus. All right. I'm done, give me a hand. Ryan pushes open the door. POP's in his 70's, but frail a in pain, which makes him seem more frail. Ryan holds out hand. Helps Pop up.

dialogues.speaker: POP RYAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Wait a goddamn minute. (reaching for his pajamas) Okay. Ryan pulls his father up. Pop pulls his pajamas up at the same time.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: You're okay. You're okay. As they head out:

dialogues.speaker: POP RYAN
dialogues.text: Stop, stop. I gotta go back. They turn around. Pop grabs hold of the sink, pulls down his pajamas and looks to his son. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: POP RYAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You gonna stand there and stare at me? Ryan moves off as Pop eases himself onto the seat, the pa obvious on his face.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: leaning against the hallway wall, staring off at the wind the first rays of dawn breaking on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darkness until the door opens -- we're close on the lock, which has been pried out of the door. Farhad steps in cautiously, hoping not to see what he knows lies ahead. H walks through the storage room and into the store where h stops dead; the place has been ransacked; what hasn't bee stolen has been smashed, racial slurs spray-painted on th walls. The front door lies open. Shaniqua, the woman from the HMO, stands there, unsure wh she just stepped into. She isn't sure she should ask, but

dialogues.speaker: SHANIQUA
dialogues.text: Do you have American Spirit Lights? Farhad goes behind the counter. There's almost nothing le He finds one pack.

dialogues.speaker: FARHAD
dialogues.text: Five seventy-five. Shaniqua hands him six.

dialogues.speaker: FARHAD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don't have change.

dialogues.speaker: SHANIQUA
dialogues.text: That's okay. She turns and exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maria enters through the French doors carrying a car seat and a cool, large mechanical monster toy. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Sorry to use your car, Mrs. Jean. I turn my key this morning, nothing. (placing toy on counter) James want to take it to school, but I no want kids to fight over it. Jean opens their custom-cabinet dishwasher and stares in.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Are these dishes clean or dirty?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: All clean.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: You know Maria, just once I'd like to wake up and find the dishes in the cupboard. Jean strides off past Maria, who immediately begins unloa the dishwasher. As Jean climbs the stairs, Maria grabs a handful of forks and reaches for the cutlery drawer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LT. JOE DIXON, African-American, stuffs some paperwork in a folder, opens his desk drawer and places the folder ins Officer Hansen stands opposite, dressed in his civilian clothes.

dialogues.speaker: HANSEN
dialogues.text: I don't want to cause any trouble, Lieutenant, I just want a new partner.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: I understand; your partner is a racist prick, but you don't want to stir up any bad feelings with him. Dixon pulls open another drawer, grabs his wallet, search for his car keys.

dialogues.speaker: HANSEN
dialogues.text: He's been on the force a long time--

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: Seventeen years. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HANSEN
dialogues.text: --and I still have to work here, sir.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: So, you don't mind that there's a racist prick on the force, you just don't want him in your car. Hansen sees he's being boxed in. Dixon finds his keys, sl the drawer shut.

dialogues.speaker: HANSEN
dialogues.text: If you need me to go on the record about this, sir, I will. Dixon crosses, puts on his coat, buttons it.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: That'd be great, write a full report. Because I am anxious to understand how such an obvious bigot could have gone undetected in this department for seventeen years, eleven of which he was personally supervised by me. Of course that doesn't speak highly of my managerial skills, but that's not your concern. Can't wait to read it. Hansen gets it loud and clear. Dixon reaches below his de grabs a wrapped X-mas gift, puts it under his arm.

dialogues.speaker: HANSEN
dialogues.text: What if I told you I wanted a new partner for personal reasons?

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: So, now you're saying he's not a racist, you just don't like him.

dialogues.speaker: HANSEN
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: That's not a good enough reason.

dialogues.speaker: HANSEN
dialogues.text: Then I should think of a better one and get back to you. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: You think I'm asking you to make one up?

dialogues.speaker: HANSEN
dialogues.text: No, sir. I just can't think of one right now. Dixon exits. Hansen follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hansen scurries to catch up.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: You want to know what I heard? I heard it was a case of uncontrollable flatulence.

dialogues.speaker: HANSEN
dialogues.text: You want me to say he has flatulence?

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: Not him; you. You have uncontrollable flatulence and are too embarrassed to ride with anyone else, so are requesting a one man car.

dialogues.speaker: HANSEN
dialogues.text: I'm not comfortable with that, Lieutenant.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: I wouldn't be either; which is why I understand your need for privacy. Just like you probably understand how hard a black man has to work to get to, say, where I am, in a racist fucking organization like the LAPD, and how easily that can all be taken away. But that said, it's your decision: (looks him in the eye) you can put your career and mine on the line in pursuit of a just cause, or you can admit to having an embarrassing problem of a personal nature. Hansen stands speechless.  3/18/04 51.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An ADA hands a document to Rick as he and Karen step out his office and head down the hall. They walk with purpose

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: He just shot the guy? Did they know each other, this some kind of grudge thing?

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Not as far as we can tell.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: You think it was racially motivated?

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: A dozen people heard the shots, no one saw anything.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Who do we have on it?

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Graham Waters.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Tell him he talks to no one but me; I want a report by three-thirty, my office. And they're gone.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: Cut! Print! Moving on. Cameron rises from his director's chair. The crew broom t set as Cameron and his FIRST A.D. head off for the next s FIRST A.D. The office called, Fred is on his way down. He has some thoughts.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: Oh, Christ. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FIRST A.D.
dialogues.text: (calling out) Okay people, moving to scene forty- six!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anthony and Peter turn onto the sidewalk, heading toward Anthony's old Toyota. They pass a skinny black kid their age.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (to kid) How's it going, Mo Phat? They bump fists and keep walking.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY
dialogues.text: Man robs purses from old ladies and you're all "How's it going, Mo Phat." Nigga would steal teeth from a cripple.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: You calling him a thief? And we do what? They climb in.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY
dialogues.text: Man steals from black people. Only reason black people steal from their own: (tries ignition) "Cause they are terrified of white people. Burbank, Santa Monica, Sherman Oaks: these are scary-ass places for a brother to find himself. (tries again) Drop "Mo Phat" off at a Starbucks in Toluca Lake, brother would run like a rvabbit-- (tries again) --soon as somebody said decaf latte-- what the fuck did you do to my car?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter and Anthony turn the corner and head down the sidew

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: No, no, no. I'm starting to understand. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PETER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: By your work you're setting an example to the neighborhood; sorta like a big brother kinda thing. Peter looks over his shoulder, sees a bus coming, waves i down.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY
dialogues.text: Laugh. You ever see me steal from a black person? What in the hell do you think you're doing?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Waving down the bus.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY
dialogues.text: Put your hand down! Are you out of your mind? You actually expect me to get on a bus?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: No, I was really hoping we could push your car into town, because we never do that anymore.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY
dialogues.text: You have no idea, do you? You have absolutely no idea why they put those great big windows on the sides of buses? One reason only: to humiliate the people of color who are reduced to riding on it.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I did not know that.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY
dialogues.text: What you don't know could fill the Staples Center.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Kings are playing tonight.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY
dialogues.text: You don't like hockey!! The only reason you say you do is to wind me up!!

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Love hockey. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Cut! Print!

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: Moving on! Real nice work, Jamal. Good work, Eddie. The crew start to break the camera and lights down. FIRST A.D. Okay, we're in scene twelve. FRED, the Executive Producer flirting with the script gir realizes that they're moving on and calls out:

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Hold on-hold on! Cam, you got a second?

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: Yeah, Fred? The AD shares a "here it comes" look with the camera oper

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: I think we need another take, buddy.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: (restraining himself) I don't know, Fred, that last one was pretty terrific.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: This is gonna sound strange, but... is Jamal seeing a speech coach or something?

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Have you noticed--this is weird for a white guy to say--but have you noticed that he's talking a lot less black lately?

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: I'm afraid I haven't noticed. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Really? This last scene, he was supposed to say, "Don't be talkin' "bout dat." And he changed it to "Don't talk to me about that."

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: And you think, because of that, people won't recognize him to be a black man?

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: ...-Is there a problem here, Cam?

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: No problem.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Because all I'm saying is it's not his character. I mean, Eddie is supposed to be the smart one. Not Jamal, right? I mean, you're the expert here, but to me it rings false.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: (decides to eat it) Okay, Fred. (calling to crew) One more, please! FIRST A.D. Everybody back, one more please!

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Thanks, buddy. Cameron heads back to his director's chair, feeling the e of the crew as they reassemble the camera and redress the set. Fred settles into the chair just behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shaniqua Johnson enters, wearing an overcoat, carrying a briefcase and finishing a Starbucks latte. CAROL, her assistant, sits behind her desk.

dialogues.speaker: SHANIQUA
dialogues.text: (checking) Morning. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Shaniqua clothes, Shaniqua

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shaniqua cubicle.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: You have a walk-in; a Mr. Ryan. turns to see Officer Ryan, dressed in his civilian who sits waiting.

dialogues.speaker: SHANIQUA
dialogues.text: Send him in. exits to...

dialogues.speaker: ADMINISTRATIVE OFFICES
dialogues.text: opens the file, looks up to see Ryan step into her She stands and holds out her hand.

dialogues.speaker: SHANIQUA
dialogues.text: Mr. Ryan my name is Shaniqua Johnson. I believe we spoke last night.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: Yeah, I wanted to apologize for that crack. I haven't been sleeping a lot. My father is in a lot of pain.

dialogues.speaker: SHANIQUA
dialogues.text: (like a stone) I'm sorry to hear that.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: This doctor he's been going to tells him he has this urinary tract infection, and he's been taking this medicine for a month now, and he's just getting worse.

dialogues.speaker: SHANIQUA
dialogues.text: (reading file) And he's been back to see Dr. Robinson?

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: Yeah, and between me and you the man is an idiot.

dialogues.speaker: SHANIQUA
dialogues.text: Really? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: No offense, but the guy sees a hundred patients an hour. I think his nurses do most of the work.

dialogues.speaker: SHANIQUA
dialogues.text: If you're unhappy, your father is welcome to see a doctor outside the network.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: And if this new doctor says it isn't an infection, says it's his prostate and it needs to be operated on, is that covered?

dialogues.speaker: SHANIQUA
dialogues.text: No. Not unless Dr. Robinson--

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: So, what good would that do?

dialogues.speaker: SHANTQUA
dialogues.text: (with finality) I'm sorry but there is nothing else I can do.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: (beat) Do you know what I can't do? I can't look at you without thinking of the five or six better qualified white men who didn't get your job.

dialogues.speaker: SHANIQUA
dialogues.text: Time for you to be going.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: I'm saying this because I'm really hoping I'm wrong about you. I'm hoping that someone like yourself, who may have been given a helping hand, might have a little compassion for someone in a similar situation. Shaniqua picks up her phone and speaks into the intercom:

dialogues.speaker: SHANIQUA
dialogues.text: Carol, I need security in my office. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The burly 58.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: You don't like me? Fine, I'ma prick. But my father doesn't deserve to suffer like this. He was a janitor, struggled his whole life, saved enough to start his own company. Twenty-three employees, all black. Paid them equal wages, when no one else was doing that. Forty years he worked side by side with those men, sweeping, carrying garbage. security guard appears at her door. She motions for him not to interrupt. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Then the city council decides to give minority-owned companies preference in city contracts. And overnight, my father loses everything. His business, his home, his wife, everything; and not once did he blame you people. (beat) I'm not asking you to help me. I'm asking that you do this small thing for a man who lost everything so that people like you could reap the benefits. And do you know what it's gonna cost you? Nothing. dust the flick of your pen.

dialogues.speaker: SHANIQUA
dialogues.text: You're father sounds like a good man. And if he'd come in here today I probably would have approved this request. But he didn't come in, you did. And for his sake, that's a real shame. (to security guard) Get him out of here. Ryan strides out of the room, past the line of cubicles, guard foll owing. Ryan's face hardens with anger as he bangs through the double glass doors.  3/18/04 59.

dialogues.speaker: INT LOCK
dialogues.text: A delivery man enters, bringing us to the OFFICE MANAGER, less than sympathetic woman.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICE MANAGER
dialogues.text: (into phone) Sir, I spoke to our employee. He told you that you needed to replace or repair the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dorri steps through the door, dressed for work, unprepare for the extent of the damage.

dialogues.speaker: FARHAD, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: He say he fix lock! You come here, see how fix it is!... Dorri drifts in, mouth agape, passing her father at the counter yelling into the phone. Sees her mother washing t walls, trying to remove the spray-painted ethnic slurs. âFuck the Towelheads." "9-11! 9-11!" "Arab Scum."

dialogues.speaker: FARHAD, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I'm not yelling, I am angry! (calls out) Shereen! Stop washing! Insurance need to take pictures! Shereen turns, sees her daughter. They embrace.

dialogues.speaker: DORRI
dialogues.text: Are you all right?

dialogues.speaker: SHEREEN
dialogues.text: I'm okay, we're okay. (turning back/in Farsi) You see what they wrote? They think we're Arabs. When did Persians become Arabs? Shereen goes back to scrubbing.

dialogues.speaker: DORRI
dialogues.text: What can I do?

dialogues.speaker: SHEREEN
dialogues.text: Go to work. Do you want to be fired, too? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DORRI
dialogues.text: I called, I switched shifts. (realizes) Oh my God. Dorri darts to the counter.

dialogues.speaker: FARHAD
dialogues.text: I want his name; give me name.

dialogues.speaker: DORRI
dialogues.text: Dad--

dialogues.speaker: OFFICE MANAGER
dialogues.text: (phone filter) Sir, I can't give you his name.

dialogues.speaker: FARHAD
dialogues.text: Bastard no fix my lock! Give me name!

dialogues.speaker: DORRI OFFICE MANAGER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Dad! I'm hanging up now, sir.

dialogues.speaker: FARHAD
dialogues.text: No hang up! No hang up on-- (click) Son-of-a-bitch! He slams down the phone.

dialogues.speaker: DORRI
dialogues.text: Did they take the gun? Farhad snaps open the hidden compartment as Dorri moves b the counter.

dialogues.speaker: THE SECRET COMPARTMENT
dialogues.text: The gun's still there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graham sweeps a bent rusty spoon and other drug paraphern off the kitchen counter into a drawer and closes it. The apartment door lies open behind him. Without removing his coat, Graham steps deeper into the apartment. He sees LOU sitting on the balcony, a woman in her fifties, on the no He steps out onto the balcony and squats beside her.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Ma?...It's cold. Her eyes flutter open but don't find him before they clos again. Graham picks her up in his arms, carries her into.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE'S LIVING ROOM 54
dialogues.text: And lays her on the sofa and pulls a blanket over her. Sh opens her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: Did you find your brother?

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: No, Ma.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: I was doing good, baby. I was doing real good.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: I know, Ma.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: (forgot she asked) Did you find your brother?

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Not yet, Ma.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: Tell him to come home. Tell him I'm not mad, okay?

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Okay. And she closes her eyes again. Graham kisses her forehead He looks to a photo on the bureau. It's a birthday party for Graham, age sixteen. Louise holds Graham's infant bro in her arms. She looks young and healthy. Better times.  55 56 57 58 3/18/04 62.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE'S REFRIGERATOR 55
dialogues.text: Graham opens it, checks out the meager contents, opens th carton of milk and smells it: rancid. He drops it in the trash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graham approaches. Ria pops open the door locks and Graha jumps in.

dialogues.speaker: RIA
dialogues.text: You apologize to your mother?

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Couldn't. She wasn't there.

dialogues.speaker: RIA
dialogues.text: Internal Affairs called. They found something in the Mercedes. Graham gives her a look as an SUV wipes frame...
