dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The grips fly a wall revealing... FIRST A.D. That's lunch, one hour! We're back at three o'clock. The crew breaks. Cameron heads for the stage door. The grips push it open and he sees Christine standing outside waiting for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She meets him and they walk together.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: I tried to call, it sounded like you were having a hard day.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: I got scared, Cam. I mean, it's not like I haven't been pulled over before. But not like that. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And I was a little drunk and I shouldn't have been mouthing off, it was stupid. But when that man put his hands on me...I just couldn't believe you'd let him do that. I know what you did was the right thing, I know that, but...I was humiliated...for you. I couldn't watch. I couldn't stand to see that man take away your dignity.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: (coldly) Yeah. That's what happened.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: Don't do this.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: You're right. Leave it at that. I've got to go. And he walks away.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: Do not walk away from me. You bastard, I apologized! Don't you walk away from me!... Cam!! He keeps going, she fights back tears and rage. Turns on her heel and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Farhad collects broken glass in the trash can. Dorri wait for KEN HO, the Korean insurance adjuster, to get off his cell phone.

dialogues.speaker: KEN HO
dialogues.text: Yeah, I understand. Thanks. (hangs up/to Dorri) Has your father read his policy? Farhad puts down the can, approaches with a look to Dorri

dialogues.speaker: DORRI
dialogues.text: He doesn't read English. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FARHAD
dialogues.text: (in Farsi) What is he saying?

dialogues.speaker: KEN HO
dialogues.text: Mr. Golzari, you told me you called the locksmith.

dialogues.speaker: FARHAD
dialogues.text: Yes, I tell him fix!

dialogues.speaker: KEN HO
dialogues.text: But they said their man told you (Dorri translates) --that you needed to replace the door, and you didn't do so.

dialogues.speaker: DORRI
dialogues.text: So you're saying it's his fault?

dialogues.speaker: KEN HO
dialogues.text: The insurance company is calling it negligence. (Dorri translates) They're not covering any of this. 64. 59 Farhad looks at Dorri, turns away, picks up the waste-pap basket full of glass and exits into the storage room.

dialogues.speaker: KEN HO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I really am sorry. He turns and exits, leaving Dorri reeling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dorri finds her father picking up trashed merchandise. tries to comfort him.

dialogues.speaker: DORRI
dialogues.text: It'll be okay, Dad, we'll figure it out.

dialogues.speaker: FARHAD
dialogues.text: Go to work.

dialogues.speaker: DORRI
dialogues.text: Dad... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FARHAD
dialogues.text: (in Farsi) You want to lose your job, too? Go to work. Dorri kisses her father's head and reluctantly leaves. Fa keeps cleaning, trying to lose himself in the work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The back door opens; officers come out in pairs and head their assigned squad cars. Hansen walks alone toward his. He sees Ryan leaning up against it, waiting. Hansen is confused and apprehensive. Ryan nods to him as he approac

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: HANSEN
dialogues.text: Hey. (an awkward beat) Maybe they didn't tell you? I've been reassigned.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: Yeah, they told me. I just wanted to say good luck and good riding with you. Ryan offers his hand. Hansen takes it, shakes. Ryan doesn let go.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Wait 'till you've been on the job a few more years.

dialogues.speaker: HANSEN
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: Look at me. Wait 'till you've been doing it a few more years. You think you know who you are? You have no idea. Ryan releases his hand, pats him on the shoulder and walk off toward his new partner, GOMEZ, who waits by his car.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yo, Carlos. We rolling? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER GOMEZ
dialogues.text: I am. They get in the car and pull out. Hansen gets in, starts the engine and keys the radio.

dialogues.speaker: HANSEN
dialogues.text: 21L23 clear.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER
dialogues.text: 21L23, I'm ha-- (fart sound) --trouble with the radio. (fart sound) --sort of strange interfer-- (fart sound)

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER
dialogues.text: Likewise, 21L-- (fart sound) --do you-- (fart) --your mike open, (fart) --any chance? Hansen clenches his jaw and drives out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A squad car passes to reveal a Detective from Internal Af popping the trunk of the Mercedes. Ria and Graham step up He throws back the floormat to reveal the wheel well -- i place of the spare tire lies stacks of bills, bound by ru bands. Lots of stacks. He slams the trunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dumpster lid bangs closed. Farhad turns and walks bac toward his store. And then he just stops; a man destroyed After what seems like an eternity he looks down at the wa paper basket dangling from his hand...and he remembers. H looks back over his shoulder and then charges the dumpste pulling out trash until he finds a crumpled blue paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan and Gomez step out of their squad car to find out wh traffic ahead is at a standstill. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over the tops of the cars they see a Hummer with a mangle fender and a piece of shit Dodge with its engine on fire, driver and passenger doors open. A white Jeep sitting whe up in the middle of the road.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: Call it in! Ryan takes off at a run toward the Jeep. He covers the distance in a few seconds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A couple of motorists stand near the inverted Jeep, unsur what to do. The roof on the driver's side has been crushe the car lies tilted forward with its hood on the ground a trunk in the air. Gasoline streams down from the ruptured tank.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: Get that engine fire out! Ryan gets to the car and drops to the pavement on the passenger side of the car. The window open. He sees the driver, scrunched upside down, still belted into her seat

dialogues.speaker: RYAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ma'am? Ma'am can you hear me? No response. Ryan puts his head through the window. Sees the gasoline dripping down into the car. Hears the soft voice of a woman crying.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ma'am? We're gonna get you out of there. Gomez runs up, looks in.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER GOMEZ
dialogues.text: Paramedics are rolling, they'll be here in two minutes. (sees gas) Jesus. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: Get an extinguisher, get that fire out. Gomez runs back to the patrol car.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ma'am, are you hurt? Can you move? Ma'am? Just quiet painful sobs. Ryan looks at:

dialogues.speaker: THE POOLING GAS, (THROUGH THE CRACKED WINDSHIELD)
dialogues.text: running out under the Jeep, in the direction of the car f

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: realizes she may not have two minutes, makes his decision

dialogues.speaker: RYAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It's okay. I'm gonna get you out. He snakes his torso into the passenger seat, leaving his feet dangling out the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan feels around for the seat buckle.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: It's okay. It's okay. Drifting out of shock, the woman turns to see Ryan's face right in front of hers and SCREAMS. It's Christine.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: No! Stay away from me! Get away from me! She flails at him.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: Lady, I'm not gonna hurt you.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: (still swinging) Don't touch me! Don't touch me! Get away from me! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: LADY! I'm trying to help you! Anger is taking over from shock:

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: Fuck you! Not you! Not you! Somebody else! Not you!! Ryan ignores her, reaches across her lap to find where th belt is snagged. She flails at him again, striking his ba

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: NO! Keep your filthy fucking hands off me!

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: Stop moving! I've almost got it!

dialogues.speaker: NOOO
dialogues.text: Ryan screams in her face:

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: Lady, I am not going to fucking hurt you! ! And she starts to sob uncontrollably. Ryan throws a look the window: gas flowing away from the car. Looks back to her.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: Please. Please. Don't touch me. And Ryan looks into her face and sees her pain and humiliation, and knows he was the cause of it. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: (quietly, kindly:) Ma'am? Ma'am, there's no one else here yet, and that's gasoline there, so we have to get you out right away. She looks, noticing the dripping gasoline for the first t

dialogues.speaker: RYAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Your seat belt is caught on something, it's jamming the buckle. Can you feel where it's caught? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She tries.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: I need to reach across your lap. Can I do that, please? She nods, fear starting to play on her face.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thanks. He reaches across her lap, tugging her skirt down a littl to cover her bare leg. He can't get it loose.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I need you to move a little, can you do that? She nods, tries to move. He jams his hand in again and wo the buckle.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Are you hurt, anything broken?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: I don't think so.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: That's good.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: Are you going to get me out?

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: Yeah, I'm gonna get you out.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: (cuts his hand) Fuck! Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: That's okay. Ryan reaches into his pocket and pulls out a jackknife. Christine reacts instinctively. He notices. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: I'm going to cut the belt, okay? She nods. Ryan saws away at it with the dullish blade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gomez gets to the flaming Dodge with the extinguisher.

dialogues.speaker: UNDER THE DODGE
dialogues.text: Catch on the trail of gasoline.

dialogues.speaker: GOMEZ 69
dialogues.text: Runs to try and beat the flames to the Jeep as a FIRE TRU arrives.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER GOMEZ
dialogues.text: Ryan! Get out of the car!

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE JEEP 70
dialogues.text: Ryan works to cut the belt. Suddenly they both notice:

dialogues.speaker: THROUGH THE WINDSHIELD 71
dialogues.text: The fire rushes toward them.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE 72
dialogues.text: shrieks, Ryan keeps cutting, just an inch to go when...

dialogues.speaker: THE FLAMES
dialogues.text: burst into the Jeep, enveloping them. Ryan cuts the belt loose. Suddenly, he's yanked out by the feet! He makes a grab for Christine.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: grabs for him, misses.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN 73
dialogues.text: is pulled from the flaming car by Gomez and a motorist. Ryan kicks at them and crawls right back in.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE 74
dialogues.text: sees him coming for her, reaches out. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: grabs her wrists. Locked together, they share a desperate look and a heartbeat later...

dialogues.speaker: GOMEZ AND TWO MOTORISTS 75
dialogues.text: pull and

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: drags Christine out with him.

dialogues.speaker: GOMEZ AND THE MOTORISTS
dialogues.text: pull Ryan and Christine away from the Jeep and toss a bla over them, smothering their smoldering clothing. In the background, the firemen arrive and attack the flames.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: sits on the pavement, cradling Christine tightly in his a as she sobs. Christine looks up at him, sobbing, confused angry, grateful -- she searches his eyes for answers, som way to make sense of what just happened.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: Shhhh. Shhhhhh. The PARAMEDICS (one of whom is Allan, the guy chasing his date in Westwood) try to lift Christine from Ryan's arms. Ryan bats him away.

dialogues.speaker: ALLAN
dialogues.text: It's okay, we just have to check her. Are you hurt? Can you walk? (she nods, they lift her to her feet) Let's take you over to the ambulance. Ryan lets her go and they walk her toward the waiting ambulance, continuing to QUESTION HER.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: throws one look back over her shoulder -- hate filled wit fear and gratitude. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: watches her, equally confused, overwhelmed and embarrasse by his feelings.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: And cut. Cameron sits slumped in his director's chair. He says nothing. The A.D. looks to him with the implied question: are we printing or doing another? Then, tentative: FIRST A.D. -So, what do you want to do? Cameron doesn't move, doesn't say anything. People start notice and grow silent. And still Cameron just sits. And the A.D. and all the crew and actors just wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A battered white Honda pulls to the curb. On the seat is open phone book. Behind the wheel sits Farhad. He looks t the house across the street. A yellow school bus pulls up blocking his view. It honks its horn and drives away, and we see a couple kids disperse onto the sidewalk. One of them waves to the others; Lara, Daniel's daughter. Lara's mother meets her and walks her inside. There's no truck i the driveway. Farhad pulls the gun out from under the phone book, opens the cylinder and sees that it is loaded. He snaps it clos and shoves it back. And waits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karen shows Graham into a conference room the size of a bowling alley. Inside we find Bruce, answering his cell phone, and JAKE FLANAGAN, kingmaker and "Head of Media Relations."

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: The D.A. asked me to apologize, he wanted to be here himself. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FLANAGAN
dialogues.text: (offers hand with a smile) No, he didn't. If he did his own dirty work, none of us would have jobs. Jake Flanagan, Media Relations. Bruce snaps shut his cell phone, to Flanagan:

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: He's just pulling into the garage.

dialogues.speaker: FLANAGAN
dialogues.text: The press conference is in ten minutes, so we'll make this short. (flips open file) Internal Affairs says this Conklin has two suspicious shootings on his record -- both black men, both times he was cleared but only just. Detective Lewis makes black man number three. You know any reason why we shouldn't hang Conklin for this?

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: It looks a little more complicated than we thought. We found over three hundred thousand dollars in the trunk of the car Lewis was driving.

dialogues.speaker: FLANAGAN
dialogues.text: Shit. (to Bruce) Get down to the garage, tell him to stay there until he hears from me. Bruce bolts for the door.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: You found the money in the Mercedes? I thought that wasn't his car.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: It's registered to a Cyndee Bradley, we haven't been able to speak to her, as she "left town" this morning.

dialogues.speaker: FLANAGAN
dialogues.text: So, it wasn't Lewis' car. He may not have even known the money was in it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: If you say so.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Latasha Harlins, Rodney King, these names ring a bell, Detective?

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: FLANAGAN
dialogues.text: We have attorneys for this slain police officer camping in our offices. We have his mother and a half-dozen men of the cloth who swear that Lewis was one of the twelve apostles of Christ. We have two black city councilmen and a congresswoman who call every hour on the hour demanding to know what the District Attorney intends to do about this and you want him to walk into that press room and tell them all that the situation is "complicated"?? A moment of silence, then a decision.

dialogues.speaker: FLANAGAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Karen) Give us a minute. Karen stands, exits.

dialogues.speaker: FLANAGAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Who knows about the money?

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: You're kidding me, right?

dialogues.speaker: FLANAGAN
dialogues.text: There are only two people in this room.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: (beat) Myself, my partner and Ferguson in Internal Affairs.

dialogues.speaker: FLANAGAN
dialogues.text: Jim Ferguson? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: FLANAGAN
dialogues.text: (beat) Okay. I guess I don't see a problem here. As it wasn't Lewis' car, the money isn't clear evidence of any wrong-doing. Even if it was, we aren't going to prosecute a dead man. Which means the money that Internal Affairs is holding can't even be considered evidence.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Well, you can do this dance, but when the Coroner's report comes in tomorrow, my bet is it says Detective Lewis was coked out of his head.

dialogues.speaker: FLANAGAN
dialogues.text: Fucking black people, huh?

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: ...I'm sorry?

dialogues.speaker: FLANAGAN
dialogues.text: I mean, I know all the sociological reasons why eighty percent of the men in prison in this state are black... schools are a disgrace, lack of opportunity, bias in the judicial system, all that stuff... but still it's gotta get to you, I mean on a gut level, as a black man. They just can't keep their hands out of the cookie jar. Graham laughs at this asshole.

dialogues.speaker: FLANAGAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Course you and I know that's not the truth, but that's the way it always plays, doesn't it. And assholes like Lewis just keep feeding the flames. It's got to get to you.

dialogues.speaker: FLANAGAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (beat) You coach ball down in Compton, am I right? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Don't try and pretend you know anything about me.

dialogues.speaker: FLANAGAN
dialogues.text: (opening a file) Oh, I know more than you think. (beat) What do you think those kids need? To make them believe; to give them hope? You think they need another greedy black asshole? Another drugdealing cop? Or do you think they need a fallen black hero?

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: If you're finished being the black man's best friend, you want to just tell me what I'm being offered here?

dialogues.speaker: FLANAGAN
dialogues.text: Oddly, the DA's squad is losing its lead investigator next month. Rick is quite adamant that his replacement be a person of color. It's a high profile position, and he wants to send the right message to the community.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: And that message is what, look at the Black Boy I bought? Thanks for thinking of me.

dialogues.speaker: FLANAGAN
dialogues.text: Actually we were thinking of you until we saw this. Flanagan slides a piece of paper out of the file and acro the table toward Graham.

dialogues.speaker: FLANAGAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It's a warrant for your brother's arrest. Twenty-something years old and already his third felony. Three Strikes Law, kid's going away for life for stealing a car. Christ that's an unfair law. But still, he had every opportunity you had. Fucking black people, huh? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: (beat) So, to make this disappear, all I have to do is frame an innocent man.

dialogues.speaker: FLANAGAN
dialogues.text: What are you, the fucking Defender of All Things White?! We're talking about a white man who shot three black men and you're arguing that maybe we're not being "fair" to him?! (beat) You know what, maybe you're right: maybe Lewis did provoke this. Maybe he got what was coming to him. Or maybe, stoned or not, just being a black man in the Valley was enough to get him killed. No one was there to see who shot first, so there is no way to know. Which means we could get this wrong. (re: warrant) Maybe that's what happened with your brother. Maybe we got it wrong. Maybe Lewis isn't the only one who deserves the benefit of the doubt. (beat) You're the one closest to all this. You need to tell us. What does your gut tell you? Graham looks to Flanagan and struggles with the decision.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flanagan has disappeared. Reporters hover in the press ro at the far end of the hall. Down at this end Graham and Karen wait uncomfortably. The stairwell door opens and Ri approaches.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: So, Graham. What do I tell them? You tell me, and I'll tell them.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: ...Given Detective Conklin's history...I'd say it's clear what happened last night.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Okay. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Rick nods and heads for the press room at the end of the hall. Karen hesitates, almost disappointed, then follows. Graham watches as Rick shakes hands with a couple of wait reporters and then disappears into the cavernous room. We hold on the open doors and push in.

dialogues.speaker: RICK, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Before I get to why we're here, I know you may have heard that we had our car stolen last night. As you can imagine, my wife is pretty shaken up, but we're both okay. And Jean and I appreciate the calls and your concern. (beat/fends off questions) Now. Just after nine p.m. last night, Detective William Lewis, an eight-year veteran of the force and an active member of the black community was gun-downed by a fellow officer. Bruce closes the doors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The thick drapes are pulled tight, it looks like a cave i here. Graham stands in the kitchen, looking at his mother passed out cold on the sofa. The image breaks his heart. He pushes it out of his mind, turns and places the two Wh Foods bags down on the counter. He opens Louise's refrigerator and fills it with groceries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cameron's black Navigator glides to a stop at a quiet intersection. It's just a stop sign and there's no cross traffic, so there's no reason for the truck to just sit t It should move on. It doesn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cameron sits, oblivious to the fact that he should be dri forward. He's lost and in pain, and not sure exactly wher he is going. And his impulse is to turn around, go home. Suddenly his passenger door jerks open and Peter levels h weapon.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Get outta the car! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Anthony shoves his gun in the driver's side window.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY
dialogues.text: Gimme the keys! Gimme the-- Anthony freezes when he sees Cameron's black face.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: --what in the fuck?!

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Get outta the car! You deaf? Get out of the car! Cameron ignores Peter, ignores the gun Anthony has pointe in his face -- just stares.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY
dialogues.text: Don't you hear the man? Get out of the muth-- Cameron flings open his door, sending Anthony flying. As Cameron steps out:

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What the fuck are you doing? You want to get killed, nigga?! The Navigator starts to roll. Peter scrambles over the se to keep the car from driving up onto the lawn, as...

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: slams the butt of his palm into Anthony's chest, knocking him back into the glare of the headlights.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: Say that again.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE DRIVER'S SEAT
dialogues.text: Stunned by what he sees, Peter jumps out to help.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Hey!

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY
dialogues.text: trips and lands awkwardly on his ass-- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY
dialogues.text: You stupid mutherfucker! --aims his gun. Cameron kicks him in the gut.

dialogues.speaker: OHHHHH
dialogues.text: Anthony buckles in two. Cameron stomps on his gun hand, pins it to the ground, and with his other foot kicks Anth in the gut, sending him rolling toward the curb. Cameron ignores the gun on the ground, just stalks Anthon

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ! Peter now has his gun aimed at Cameron's back.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I'll shoot you! Back off or I'll shoot you! Cameron kicks Anthony again.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Stop kicking him! I'11 shoot you dead!

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: You get out of the car!

dialogues.text: I'll blow you away! Get outta the car!

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: You get out of the car!

dialogues.text: Get the fuck out of the car! Cameron swerves around a corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Hansen, reading the plate number into his radio-- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: 4PCI --
dialogues.text: (realizes) I know this guy.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: You get out of the fucking car!!

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY
dialogues.text: Get out of the fucking car!!

dialogues.text: Get out of my car! Suddenly Cameron slams on the brakes. And

dialogues.text: Cul-de-sacs! Another fucking reason black people have no business living in Sherman Oaks! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: brakes at the entrance to the cul-de-sac. The other squad goes right past, pulling in behind the Navigator. Stone grabs the shotgun and he and Hill spring out, guns drawn aimed.

dialogues.text: Hands in plain sight! Step out of the vehicle!

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: Get out of my car!

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY
dialogues.text: You so brave, you get outta the car!

dialogues.speaker: HANSEN
dialogues.text: pulls his sidearm and assumes a backup position.

dialogues.text: Cameron turns to Anthony, who is hunching down in his sea

dialogues.text: Hands in plain sight, step out of the vehicle! Cameron pulls up his sweater and jams the handgun into th belt in the small of his back. He flings open the door an steps out into..

dialogues.text: You get on your knees and suck my dick while you're down there!

dialogues.speaker: HANSEN
dialogues.text: I know this man!

dialogues.speaker: HANSEN
dialogues.text: I know this man!

dialogues.text: Get out of the way!

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER STONE

dialogues.speaker: HANSEN

dialogues.text: (to Officer Hill) Fuck you! Hansen spins on Cameron.

dialogues.speaker: HANSEN
dialogues.text: You see what's happening here? You want to die here?! Is that what you want?? 'Cause these guys really want to shoot you, and the way you are acting they will be completely fucking justified.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: Fuck you.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER HILL
dialogues.text: Step away from him!

dialogues.text: (to Cameron) Fuck me? I'm not the one who is fucked here! You're the one who is fucked, 'cause you're the one who is gonna have his head blown across the street and onto that man's patio!

dialogues.text: Officer Hansen, step away now!

dialogues.text: (turns on them) He's a friend of mine, ok?! He's a fucking friend of mine! He is not armed and he is not gonna shoot me or anybody else! So give me two fucking seconds here! Stone and Hill share a look. Hill lowers his weapon and steps away, really pissed. Stone keeps the shotgun traine Hansen steps back to Cameron and speaks softly.

dialogues.speaker: HANSEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Are you starting to understand the situation here? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The shock is wearing off and Cameron is starting to grasp the insanity of the situation.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: ..-What the fuck you want?

dialogues.speaker: HANSEN
dialogues.text: Unless you think your wife is gonna be better off with a husband who has a bloody stump for a head, I want you to sit on that curb, put your hands on your head and do nothing until I speak to these officers.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: I'm not putting my hands on my head or sitting on any fucking curb!

dialogues.speaker: HANSEN
dialogues.text: Then stand where you are and keep your hands in plain sight! Can you do that?

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: ....Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: HANSEN
dialogues.text: (to other cops) I've told this man to stay where he is and keep his hands in plain sight. Hansen approaches Hill. Stone moves to join in the conversation.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER HILL
dialogues.text: This man better be related to you by blood, because this is fuckin' nuts.

dialogues.speaker: HANSEN
dialogues.text: --I need this favor. You can run his name and license -- there's no priors, no warrants. I need to let him go with a warning.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER HILL
dialogues.text: ..-What kind of fucking warning?

dialogues.speaker: HANSEN
dialogues.text: A harsh warning. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Reads the stunned silence as agreement.

dialogues.speaker: HANSEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thanks. Hansen walks back to Cameron.

dialogues.speaker: HANSEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (angrily) You've been warned, you understand? Do you understand me? Cameron stares back defiantly.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: You want to do something to me? I'm right here.

dialogues.speaker: HANSEN
dialogues.text: I am trying to fucking help you.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: Did I ask for your help?

dialogues.speaker: HANSEN
dialogues.text: (beat) Go home.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: That I can do. Cameron turns, walks back to the Navigator, opens the doo and climbs in.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY
dialogues.text: stares at him as if he is a patient from an insane asylum Cameron pulls shut his door. Cameron starts the engine as Hansen turns and walks back to the other cops.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER HILL
dialogues.text: You're writing this up. The cops get back into their cars as the Navigator pulls past them and cruises off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anthony stares up from the floor in disbelief, tries to f out what in the hell just happened.  92 93 94 95 96 3/18/04 91.

dialogues.text: The Navigator disappears and the cops back out. As they pass Hansen, Stone shakes his head. Then they're gone, leaving Hansen standing alone in the cul-de-sac.

dialogues.text: Cameron drives down Ventura Blvd. Anthony slowly pulls himself up into his seat, still trying to figure out what Cameron's angle is here. Cameron pulls over to the curb.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: Look at me. Cameron hands him back his gun.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You embarrass me. You embarrass yourself. For the first time in his life, Anthony's got nothing to say. He shoves his gun into his pocket and gets out, and the Navigator pulls away. He walks off down the sidewalk.

dialogues.text: How's it going? The black officer just gives him a look and walks off out the door. Hansen looks around, sees the last few officers exit in their civvies, completely ignoring him. Now alone, Hansen leans back against the wall and watches the last drop of daylight disappear from the room. And suddenly he slams his locker closed.

dialogues.text: Jean pads up the back stairs. She's wearing her workout clothes and a pair of sweat socks, the cordless phone to ear. She heads down the hall carrying a book and a stuffe animal. She drops off the animal in her son's room and ke walking under the following:

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: I sent her for groceries, that was two hours ago.... Carol, you should talk, you go through six housekeepers a year.... I'm not snapping at you, I'm just angry; I'm sorry.... (with growing agitation) Yes, at them! And the police and Rick and Maria and the dry cleaner who ruined another blouse and the gardener who keeps over-watering the lawn and.... (stops, grapples with an explanation) I just woke up this morning and I thought I'd feel better. You know? But I was still mad...and I realized : it wasn't about having my car stolen. That's how I wake up every morning....I'm angry all the time. (at the point of tears) And I don't know why. Carol, I don't know why. (beat/listens) Yeah, call me back. She hangs up the phone and heads for the front stairs. He foot slips on the top step and she falls.  105 106 107 108 109 3/18/04

dialogues.text: Hansen drives home, barely listening to the country and western song that plays softly on the radio, his mind on night's events. He passes a hitch-hiker but thinks nothing of it, just an black kid. Something makes him reconsider. He pulls ove He 106 ight 107 ds, s 108 No a 109 the other xr and Peter runs up to the car, opens the door and climbs i

dialogues.text: Really appreciate this. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: No problem. Being a cop, Hansen can't help checking Peter out.

dialogues.speaker: HANSEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don't usually stop.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Don't usually hitch.

dialogues.speaker: HANSEN
dialogues.text: How long you been out there?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Hour maybe.

dialogues.speaker: HANSEN
dialogues.text: That's a big surprise.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Yeah, this ain't exactly pick up a brother territory.

dialogues.speaker: HANSEN
dialogues.text: (smiles) True. So, where you heading?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Anywhere the other side of the hill.

dialogues.speaker: HANSEN
dialogues.text: I'm going to El Segundo.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: El Segundo's cool.

dialogues.speaker: HANSEN
dialogues.text: You been there?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Fuck no. (a moment) Good music. Hansen gives him a look. He doesn't believe that either.

dialogues.speaker: PETER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No, really. I'm starting to understand it. Wrote a country song myself just yesterday. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HANSEN
dialogues.text: I'll bet you did.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: My hand to God. We notice Hansen is tapping his left leg double time to t music, a little too fast. The adrenaline is still pumping through him, and he's fighting it.

dialogues.speaker: PETER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That's some rhythm you got working. Hansen gives him a sideways glance; pays a little more attention to his clothing now, particularly the small tea in his baggy coat.

dialogues.speaker: HANSEN
dialogues.text: So, what was happening in the Valley tonight? Hansen notices the mud coating Peter's sneakers.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Ice skating.

dialogues.speaker: HANSEN
dialogues.text: Ice skating?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Love to skate. Always wanted to be a goalie. Hansen forces a chuckle.

dialogues.speaker: PETER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You think that's funny?

dialogues.speaker: HANSEN
dialogues.text: I think you're having fun.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Whatever. Peter lets it go, but it still digs at him. Then he notic the plastic statue of St. Christopher on the dash. And he starts to laugh.

dialogues.speaker: HANSEN
dialogues.text: Something else funny? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (still laughing) Oh yeah.

dialogues.speaker: HANSEN
dialogues.text: So, what's that?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: dust people, man.

dialogues.speaker: HANSEN
dialogues.text: People like me?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: No, man, I'm not laughing at you.

dialogues.speaker: HANSEN
dialogues.text: Yeah, I can see that. How about you laugh outside? And he does.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Why you getting all bent outta shape?

dialogues.speaker: HANSEN
dialogues.text: I'm not getting bent, just pulling over.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Come on, man, keep driving, I said I'm not laughing at you.

dialogues.speaker: HANSEN
dialogues.text: And I'm not telling you to get out of my car.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Why you being a jerk? Drive the car.

dialogues.speaker: HANSEN
dialogues.text: I gotta better idea, why don't you get out right now.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Fine. You want me to show you? I'll show you. Peter thrusts his hand deep into his jacket pocket. Hanse reacts instinctively: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: Take your hand out of your pocket!

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Fuck you.

dialogues.speaker: HANSEN
dialogues.text: Put your hands where I can see them!

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Who the fuck do you think you are?

dialogues.speaker: HANSEN
dialogues.text: Hands in plain sight!

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: You wanna see what's in my hand?! I'll show you what's in my fucking hand! Peter jerks his hand up out of his pocket and Hansen swin his revolver out with his left hand and fires.... hitting Peter dead in the chest. Peter looks down at the hole in his chest, looks at his right hand, opens it to reveal th plastic statuette.

dialogues.speaker: HANSEN
dialogues.text: Oh God. Oh God. And it's obvious to both of them that Peter is going to d And Hansen reaches over for him, and supports his neck as Peter gurgles blood...and looks back at Hansen, dumfounde And while they look in each other's eyes, Peter dies. And Hansen panics.

dialogues.speaker: HANSEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh God. Oh no. Oh God. His mind racing, Hansen reaches over and opens the passen door...and Peter falls out.

He looks at the other occupants of the bus, an old black couple and three Hispanic housekeepers, laughin in the midst of an animated story. And he thinks "this is my fucking life." And looks back out the window. And sees something he recognizes. He yanks at the bell and stands.

dialogues.speaker: A SET OF CAR KEYS
dialogues.text: They hang in the lock of the van door, exactly as we last saw them. Anthony's hand reaches in and turns them. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: REVEAL ANTHONY AND "THE CHINAMAN'S" PANEL VAN
dialogues.text: Anthony climbs in, turns the engine over and drives off d the deserted street. Smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kim Lee, the Korean Woman who rear-ended Ria, frantically searches the rooms on either side of the hospital corrido

dialogues.speaker: KIM LEE
dialogues.text: Choi Jin Gui! Choi Jin Gui! A NURSE steps out into her path, stops her.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE HODGES
dialogues.text: Can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: KIM LEE
dialogues.text: Choi Jin Gui! Choi Jin Gui!

dialogues.speaker: NURSE HODGES
dialogues.text: Do you speak English?

dialogues.speaker: KIM LEE
dialogues.text: I am speak English, you stupid cow! My husband name Choi Jin Gui!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The nurse opens the door and Kim Lee bursts in, hysterica

dialogues.speaker: KIM LEE
dialogues.text: Jin Gui! Oh God, Jin Gui!

dialogues.speaker: NURSE HODGES
dialogues.text: Ma'am-- The nurse gives up and exits and Kim Lee runs to her husb bed and throws her arms around him. Choi, "The Chinaman," his body bandaged and cast, sees her through drug-heavy e

dialogues.speaker: CHOI
dialogues.text: ...Kim Lee?

dialogues.speaker: KIM LEE
dialogues.text: (in Korean) I thought you were dead -- I called every hospital. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CHOI
dialogues.text: It's okay, I'm okay. She kisses him repeatedly, as if barely believing he is a

dialogues.speaker: KIM LEE
dialogues.text: I went crazy, speeding. I drove into a car.

dialogues.speaker: CHOI
dialogues.text: Oh my God, are you all right?

dialogues.speaker: KIM LEE
dialogues.text: (nods, then...) Got in big fight with poor woman. Call her names. He laughs through the pain.

dialogues.speaker: KIM LEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh fine, I die from worry, you laugh.

dialogues.speaker: CHOI
dialogues.text: (squeezes her hand) Thank you...for finding me. She smiles through tears.

dialogues.speaker: CHOI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Will you do something for me?

dialogues.speaker: KIM LEE
dialogues.text: Anything.

dialogues.speaker: CHOT
dialogues.text: Go to the locker. She walks to the four lockers that line the entrance to t ward.

dialogues.speaker: CHOI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The next one. She finds it, opens it.

dialogues.speaker: CHOI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: In my shirt pocket. She reaches in, pulls out a check -- the company check th the other Korean man gave him in the deli. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CHOI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Bring it here. She does. He motions her to lean close. He folds it into her hand and whispers into her ear.

dialogues.speaker: CHOI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (in Korean) Cash it right away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RIA walks slowly along the corridor. Covered bodies on gurneys line the wall, overflow from the crowded morgue. She braces herself, then turns and looks back down the corridor, to see.... GRAHAM AND LOUISE standing further down the hall in front one particular gurney. The female coroner tech flips back the sheet enough for them to see. Louise's legs buckle. Her face contorts, her mouth opens, no sound able to esca RIA turns away, unable to watch as... THE PATHOLOGIST covers the body, offers a sympathetic loo and exits. As she gets closer we realize that she is Dorr Farhad's daughter. She approaches the wall phone in the hall, it's hold light flashing. She answers it quietly.

dialogues.speaker: DORRI
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graham and Ria lower Louise onto a bench.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: My baby, my poor baby. Ria walks to the nearby dispenser to get Louise some wate Graham, his face tear-stained, kneels beside his mother.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Shh. It's ok. Shhhh. I promise you. I promise you I'll find out who did this to him.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: I already know. Graham looks back, confused. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You did. His mind reels as he tries to grasp her meaning.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I asked you to find your brother. But you were busy. We weren't much good to you anymore, were we? As her meaning stabs him in the heart...

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You got things to do. You go ahead, I'll sign the papers.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: -Ma?

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: I just want to wait with my baby. Graham gets to his feet and somehow finds the strength to walk down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He came home. You know that? My little boy. When I was sleeping. He brought me groceries. Last thing he did. Graham nods, turns and walks past Ria, barely looking at her. Ria watches him go, her heart breaking for them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anthony talks to Lucien. We see the van parked in b.g.

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: No, I get it; when I said "get me a black Lincoln Navigator", you thought I said "get me a white piece of shit panel van."

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY
dialogues.text: Just give me whatever. Georgie opens the back doors.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: Lucien? You should see this. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Lucien and Anthony step to the rear of the panel van, loo in to see:

dialogues.speaker: A DOZEN OR SO ILLEGAL ALIENS
dialogues.text: All Asian; incredibly thin, scared, their clothes filthy urine drenched, chained together, men, women and children the chain locked to the van with a padlock. Lucien and Anthony are speechless. Until...

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: I'll take the van.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY
dialogues.text: They're chained to the van.

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: So, I'll take them, too.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY
dialogues.text: You want to buy these Chinamen?

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: Don't be ignorant. They're Thai or something; entirely different kinda chinks. How much you want for them? Georgie, count âem up. As Georgie counts:

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY
dialogues.text: What the hell you gonna do with them?

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: Sell âem, what the hell you think? I'll give you five hundred a piece and you can keep the van. Anthony looks at the Illegals and...

dialogues.speaker: MARIA, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Mister Rick?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rick shuffles the papers under his arm as as he strains t hear his cell phone.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Maria? What's wrong?  3/18/04 107.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Mrs. Jean needs to talk to you. Maria hands the phone to Jean, who sits in bed, her ankle taped and propped on a pillow.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Rick?

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: I fell on the stairs. He pushes the elevator button.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: When I couldn't reach you I called everyone; Julie and Marg and Suz....

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: (checks his watch/shit) I'm leaving right now.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: It's okay, Maria drove me; it's just a bad sprain. I couldn't get through to anyone. Carol was the only one home. She said she couldn't come, she was having a massage. She's been my friend ten years.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: The bitch. You okay?

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Yeah, I'm okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karen steps up beside him at the elevators.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: I'm on my way. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JEAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Okay. A brief look passes from Rick to Karen: it's not going to happen tonight. She understands. The elevator doors open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jean puts the phone back on the cradle as Maria returns w a cup of tea.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: You want to sit up? Jean nods. Maria puts the cup down. She wraps her arms around Jean's shoulders and pulls her up so that Jean's leaning against the headboard. Maria goes to move away, b Jean holds on. Her eyes are tearing up.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: You want to hear something funny?... You're the best friend I have. Maria rubs her back as Jean holds on tight. INT. THE CHINAMAN'S PANEL VAN -- NIGHT 11%. Anthony drives alone in the night, through a desolate par of town. A slim hand reaches through the chain-link divid behind the seat, the fingers touch his head. Anthony jerk his head away. Another tiny hand reaches out and touches his ear. Anthony swats it away. A third hand reaches to touch his head, then a fourth, a fifth. Anthony tries to ignore them now, just keeps his eyes on the road and driv into the night. Suddenly his face is lit by a distant fireball reaching into the sky. Anthony turns and looks across the distant dirt field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the fireball settles, the flames consume a 1993 shit-b Crown Victoria. Hansen tosses a gas can into the field an walks away, silhouetted by the flames. He peels off his work gloves and stuffs them in his pocket. When we finall see his face clearly we can tell he is a man destroyed, l no idea how he got here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dark, save for the moonlight filtering through the window The glass door opens, Dorri enters. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The headlights of a passing car reveal Farhad sitting alo in the empty market, the gun in his hand, his face ashen strained. Dorri crosses to her father, squats before him. He looks into her eyes, tries to find the words, can't. She stares down at the gun, fearing the worst.

dialogues.speaker: DORRI
dialogues.text: What did you do? (no answer) Dad, what did you do?

dialogues.speaker: FARHAD
dialogues.text: I shot a little girl. Dorri gasps.

dialogues.speaker: FARHAD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She's fine. She isn't hurt. I was this far from her, I shot her in the back.

dialogues.speaker: DORRI
dialogues.text: Oh my god.

dialogues.speaker: FARHAD
dialogues.text: (in Farsi) She was my firishta.

dialogues.speaker: DORRI
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: FARHAD
dialogues.text: My firishta. You don't know your faith. She was my angel. She saved me. She saved us all. (offers her the gun) Take it. Please. Dorri takes it.

dialogues.speaker: THE REGISTER
dialogues.text: Dorri opens the hidden compartment, looks in to see the r box of ammo she placed there. For the first time we're cl enough to read the label: .32 SMITH & WESSON BLANK Black Powder BLANKS. She slips the box into her purse, checking to see if her father noticed.  120 121 122 123 124 3/18/04

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cameron drives, staring ahead. through the windshield.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snow falls all around the car. lot on the corner just ahead.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: doesn't know what the hell he's car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cameron gets out, marvelling at him. He touches a flake on his black. Ash. black kids who should be in bed the car fire, table, having a heck of a time, them. He crosses the street, throwing junk in - cardboard boxes, 110. 126

dialogues.speaker: STREET
dialogues.text: Suddenly he notices something A fire burns in the vacant looking at. He stops the 121 the "snow" falling all around white shirt it smears to where a half a dozen all dance and play around an old as ash rains down all around Cameron joins them, watching the Crown Victoria burn, wat the kids laugh and chase each other. He smiles to himself. His cell phone rings. He checks the readout: HOME.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking in through their window we see Christine sitting the bed in the dark, wearing her sweats, hair wet, lookin scraped and worse for the wear, phone to her ear.

dialogues.speaker: WITH CAMERON 123
dialogues.text: Staring at the readout. He finally makes the decision and presses TALK.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: (tenderly) Hi.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE 124
dialogues.text: Almost cries.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON 125
dialogues.text: Watches the boys play. One of them tosses a broken chair the fire. Cameron smiles.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE 126
dialogues.text: brushes away the tears that fall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking in from outside we see Ryan, hands bandaged, help his frail and aging father into the bathroom. After some difficulty he eases him down onto the toilet. Where his father weeps. No apparent reason, just weeps. And Ryan kisses his forehead and holds him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lara sleeps in her parents' bed, nestled close to her mot Daniel stands at the window, looking out into the night.. wondering if that bullet is still out there somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rick locks the kitchen door, the lock we saw Daniel repla Something makes him unlock it and lock it again. And then he slowly looks up, at the darkness of the yard beyond. A he stands there, unable to move, now finally alone, all h fears washing over him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All that's left is the crime scene tape. Graham stands al in the headlights of his own car. He fingers the cracked St. Christopher statuette in his hand, then stares out in the long grass; lost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The streets are busy, but most people just hurry on their way. The Chinaman's panel van pulls to a stop, a couple cars back from the light. Anthony looks around, sees all the Chinese. He puts the v in park, yanks the keys out of the ignition and walks aro back. He flings open the back door of the van, stuffs a key in padlock and pulls out the chain. The chain slips through the metal cuffs on their ankles. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The Illegals stare at him, unmoving. : Anthony yells at them:

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY
dialogues.text: Pull âem off! He pries open one of the anklets to show them how. The ot kids follow his example.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come on-come on-come on, this is America, time is money. One of the kids steps out of the van, then another.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Chop-chop, let's go. And from there, two dozen wide-eyed Illegals step out int the street and get their first real look at America. They weave off through traffic, and down the crowded sidewalk. ONE stops at a fruit and vegetable stand, marvelling at t variety of produce -- pokes something strange. ANOTHER TWO step out of the van and find the fish market they laugh and finger the fish on ice. The MARKET OWNER rushes out of his store YELLING in CHINE and shooing them away. ANOTHER COUPLE stop at the store displaying bins of CD's and push a stack back and forth like dominoes. A FRIGHTENED man squats on the sidewalk, his back to a sh wall, watches the passing faces, nodding hellos to strang who ignore him. A WOMAN walks, stunned and awed by the signs above her, b jostled and bumped by stern-faced pedestrians.

dialogues.speaker: BACK AT THE VAN
dialogues.text: An impatient driver behind the van lays on the horn. The last few Illegal climbs out of the van. Anthony stuffs a couple twenties in one man's hand.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You split that up. Buy everybody chop-suey, you understand? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The man walks off into the street.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Dopey fucking Chinamen. Anthony closes the back door, climbs back into the van an drives off. As he disappears around the corner

dialogues.speaker: A CAR
dialogues.text: brakes hard in the extreme foreground and is immediately REAR ENDED.

dialogues.speaker: THE DRIVER
dialogues.text: of the first car climbs out. It's Shaniqua.

dialogues.speaker: SHANIQUA
dialogues.text: What in the hell is wrong with you people? The two HISPANIC OCCUPANTS of the second car step out and argue with her in Spanish.

dialogues.speaker: SHANIQUA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don't talk to me unless you can speak American. A CHINESE STORE OWNER decides to set her straight.

dialogues.speaker: SHANIQUA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to store owner) You mind your own business and -- (to Hispanic Driver) You show me your insurance. (more argument) Don't pretend you don't know what I'm talking about: the word starts with the letters I-N-S, which is who I'm gonna call if you don't hand it over pronto. And as we rise we see the twisted chaos of the intersecti the cars and the people and the Illegals disappearing int the maw of the churning city. And it starts to snow.
